sp.p: What madmen are not possessed with this love? yet by my troth, we poor women do but smile in our sleeves to see all this foppery: yet we all desire to see our lovers attired gallantly, to hear them sing sweetly, to behold them dance comely and such like; but this apish monkey fashion of effeminate niceness, out upon it: o, I hate it worse than to be counted a scold.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: Indeed men are most regarded, when they least regard themselves.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And women most honoured, when they show most mercy to their lovers.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.p: But is't not a miserable tyranny, to see a lady triumph in the passions of a soul languishing through her cruelty?

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: methinks it is.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: methinks 'tis more than tyranny.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: So think not I: for as there is no reason to hate any that love us, so it were madness to love all that do not hate us: women are created beautiful, only because men should woo them: for 'twere miserable tyranny to enjoin poor women to woo men: I would not hear of a woman in love for my father's kingdom.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.p: I never heard of any woman that hated love.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Nor I: but we had all rather die than confess we love; our glory is to hear men sigh whilst we smile, to kill them with a frown, to strike them dead with a sharp eye, to make you this day wear a feather, and tomorrow a sick nightcap: o, why this is rare, there's a certain deity in this, when a lady by the magic of her looks, can turn a man into twenty shapes.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.p: Sweet friend, she speaks this but to torture me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I'll teach thee how to plague her: love her not.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Poor Orleans, how lamentably he looks: if he stay, he'll make me surely love him for pure pity. I must send him hence, for of all sorts of love. I hate the French: I pray thee, sweet prisoner, entreat lord Longavile to come to me presently.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.p: I will: and esteem myself more than happy, that you will employ me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Watch him, watch him for god's sake, if he sigh not or look not back.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.p: He does both: but what mystery lies in this?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Nay, no mystery, 'tis as plain as Cupid's forehead: why this is as it should be: and esteem myself more than happy, that you will employ me: my French prisoner is in love over head and ears.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: Its wonder how he scapes drowning.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: With whom think you?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
With his keeper, for a good wager: ah, how glad is he to obey? And how proud am I to command in this empire of affection? Over him and such spongy-livered youths, (That lie soaking in love) I triumph more with mine eye,
than ever he did over a soldier with his sword. Is't not a gallant victory for me to subdue my father's enemy with a look? Prince of Cyprus, you were best take heed, how you encounter an English lady.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: God bless me from loving any of you, if all be so cruel.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: God bless me from suffering you to love me, if you be not so formable.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.p: Will you command me any service, as you have done Orleans:

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: No other service but this, that (As Orleans) you love me, for no other reason, but that I may torment you.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: I will: conditionally, that in all company I may call you my tormenter.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p: You shall: conditionally, that you never beg for mercy. Come, my lord of Galloway.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Come, sweet madam. Exeunt.

div.stage: Manet Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: The ruby-coloured portals of her speech
Were closed by mercy: but upon her eye,
(Attired in frowns) sat murdering cruelty. Enter Agrip. and listens.
She's angry, that I durst so high aspire.
O, she disdains that any stranger's breast
Should be a temple for her deity:
She's full of beauty, full of bitterness.
Till now, I did not dally with love's fire:
And when I thought to try his flames indeed,
I burned me even to cinders: oh, my stars,
Why from my native shore did your beams guide me,
To make me dote on her that doth deride me?

div.stage: She kneels: he walks musing.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p: Hold him in this mind, sweet Cupid, I conjure thee. O, what music these hey-hoes make? I was about to cast my little little self into a great love trance for him, fearing his heart had been flint: but since I see 'tis pure virgin wax, he shall melt his belly full: for now I know how to temper him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Never beg mercy? yet be my tormenter. I'll spies her.
I hope she heard me not: doubtless she did:
and now will she insult upon my passions,
And vex my constant love with mockeries.
Nay, then I'll be mine own physician,
And our face love, and make her think that I
Mourned thus, because I saw her standing by.
What news, my lord of Cornwall?

div.stage: Enter Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Cornew.
sp.l: This fair prince,
One of your countrymen, is come to court,
A lusty gallant brave in Cyprus I'll,
With fifty bard horses prancing at his heels,
Backed by as many strong limbed Cypriots.
All whom he keeps in pay: whose offred service,
Our King with arms of gladness hath embraced.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Born in the I'll of Cyprus? what's his name?

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: His servants call him Fortunatus' son.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Rich Fortunatus' son? Is he arrived?

div.stage: Enter Longavile, Galloway, and Chester with jewels.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: This he bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And this on me.

sp.speaker: Gallow.
sp.l: And this bounteous hand enforced me take.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I prize this jewel at a hundred marks,
Yet would he needs bestow this gift on me.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: My lords, whose hand hath been thus prodigal?

sp.speaker: Gallow.
sp.l: Your countryman my lord, a cypriot.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The gallant sure is all compact of gold,
To every lady hath he given rich jewels,
And sent to every servant in the court
Twenty fair English angels.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: This is rare.

div.stage: Enter Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: My lords, prepare yourselves for revelling,
'Tis the King's pleasure that this day he spent
In royal pastimes, that this golden lord,
(For so all that behold him, christen him)
may taste the pleasures of our English court.
Here comes the gallant, shining like the sun.

div.stage: Trumpets sound: enter Athelstane, Andelocia, Agripyne, Orleans, ladies, and other attendants, Insultado a Spanish lord: music sounds within.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: For these your royal favours done to me,
(Being a poor stranger) my best powers shall prove,
By acts of worth, the soundness of my love.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Herein your love shall best set out itself,
By staying with us: if our English I'll
Hold any object welcome to your eyes,
Do but make choice, and claim it as your prize.

div.stage: The King and Cyprus confer aside.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: I thank your grace: would he durst keep his word,
I know what I would claim: tush, man, be bold,
Were she a saint, she may be won with gold.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: 'Tis strange I must confess, but in this pride,
His father Fortunatus (If he live)
Consumes his life in Cyprus: still he spends,
And still his coffers with abundance swell,
But how he gets these riches none can tell.

div.stage: The King and Agripyne confer aside.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Hold him in talk: come hither, Agrippine.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: But what enticed young Andelocia's soul
To wander hither?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: That which did allure,
My sovereign's son, the wonder of the place.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: This curious heap of wonders, (Which an empress
Gave him) he gave me, and by Venus' hand,
The warlike Amorato needs would swear,
He left his country Cyprus for my love.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: If by the sovereign magic of thine eye,
Thou canst inchant his looks to keep the circles
Of thy fair cheeks, be bold to try thy charms,
Feed him with hopes, and find the royal vein,
that leads this cypriot to his golden mine.
Here's music spent in vain, lords, fall to dancing.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: My fair tormentor, will you lend a hand?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I'll try this strangers cunning in a dance.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: My cunning is but small, yet who'll not prove
To shame himself for such a lady's love?

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: These Cypriots are the devils that torture me.
He courts her, and she smiles, but I am born,
To be her beauty's slave, and her love's scorn.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I shall never have the face to ask the question twice.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: What's the reason? Cowardliness or pride?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Neither: but 'tis the fashion of us Cypriots, both men and women, to yield at first assault, and we expect others should do the like.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: It's a sign, that either your women are very black, and are glad to be sped, or your men very fond, and will take no denial.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Indeed our ladies are not so fair as you.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: But your men more venturous at a breach than you, or else they are all dastardly soldiers.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: He that fights under these sweet colours, and yet turns coward, let him be shot to death with the terrible arrows of fair lady's eyes.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.p: Nay Insultado, you must not deny us.

sp.speaker: Insultad.
sp.p: My corocon es muy pesada, my anima muy atormentada,No per los Cielos: la piede deespagnoll, no haze musica in tierra inglesa.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Sweet Insultado let us see you dance.
I have heard the Spanish dance is full of state.

sp.speaker: Insultad.
sp.l: Verdad signior: la danza spagnola, es muy alta,
Maiestica, y para monarcas: vuestra inglesa,
Baxa, fantastica, y muy humilde.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Doth my Spanish prisoner deny to dance? He has sworn to me by the cross of his pure Toledo, to be my servant: by that oath (My Castilian prisoner) I conjure you to show your cunning, though all your body be not free, I am sure your heels are at liberty.

sp.speaker: Insultad.
sp.p: Nolo choir contra dezir: vuestra oio haze conquesto a su prisionero: oyes, la pavyne Hispanola, sea vuestra musica y gravidad, y maiestad: pay, dadime tobacco, ton●a my capa, e my espada. Mas alta, mas alta: desuiaios, desuiaios, companieros, mas alta, mas alta.

div.stage: He dances.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Thanks, Insultado.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: 'Tis most excellent.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The Spaniards dance, is as his deeds be, full of pride.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: The day grows old, and what remains unspent,
Shall be consumed in banquets, Agrippine,
Leave us a while, if Andelocia please,
Go bear our beauteous daughter company. Exeunt Agrip. and Andel. and ladies.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Fortune I thank thee: now thou smilest on me.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: This cipriot bears a gallant princely mind.
My lord, of what birth is your countryman?
Think not, sweet prince, that I propound this question,
To wrong you in your love to Agrippine:
Our favours grace him to another end.
Nor let the wings of your affection droop,
Because she seems to shun love's gentle lure.
Believe it on our word, her beauty's prize
Only shall yield a conquest to your eyes.
But tell me what's this Fortunatus' son?

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Of honourable blood, and more renowned
In foreign kingdoms (Whither his proud spirit,
Plumed with ambitious feathers, caries him)
Then in his native country. but last day,
The father and the sons were through their riots,
Poor and disdained of all, but now they glister,
More bright than Midas: if some damned fiend
Fed not his bags, this golden pride would end.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: His pride we'll somewhat tame, and curb the head
Of his rebellious prodigality:
He hath invited us, and all our peers,
To feast with him tomorrow, his provision,
I understand may entertain thrée Kings.
But Lincoln, let our subjects secretly
Be charged on pain of life that not a man
Sell any kind of fuel to his servants.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: This policy shall clip his golden wings,
And teach his pride what 'tis to strive with Kings.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Withdraw a while:Exeunt. Manet Athelstane.
None filled his hands with gold, for we set spies,
To watch who fed his prodigality:
He hung the marble bosom of our court,
As thick with glistering spangles of pure gold,
As ere the spring hath stucked the earth with flowers.
Unless he melt himself to liquid gold,
Or be some god, some devil, or can transport
A mint about him, (By enchanted power)
He cannot rain such showers: with his own hands
He threw more wealth abroad in every street,
Then could be thrust into a chariot:
He's a magician sure, and to some fiend,
His soul (By infernal covenants) has he sold,
Always to swim up to the chin in gold.
Be what he can be, if those doting fires,
Wherein he burns for Agrippina's love,
Want power to melt from him this endless mine,
Then (Like a slave) we'll chain him in our tower,
Where tortures shall compel his sweating hands
To cast rich heaps into our treasury.

div.stage: Music sounding still: a curtain being drawn, where Andelocia lies sleeping in Agrippine's lap, she has his purse, and herself and another lady tie another (Like it) in the place, and then rise from him.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I have found the sacred spring that never ebbs.
Leave us:Exit lady.but I'll not show't your majesty,
Till you have sworn by England's royal crown,
To let me keep it.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: By my crown I swear,
None but fair Agrippine the gem shall wear.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Then is this mine: see, father, here's the fire,
Whose gilded beams still burn, this is the sun,
That ever shines, the tree that never dies,
Here grows the garden of Hesperides,
The outside mocks you, makes you think 'tis poor,
But entering it, you find eternal store.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Art sure of this? How didst thou drive it out?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Fear not his waking yet, I made him drink
That soporiferous juice which was composed,
To make the Queen (My mother) relish sleep,
When her last sickness summoned her to heaven.
He sleeps profoundly: when his amorous eyes
Had singed their wings in Cupid's wanton flames,
I set him all on fire, and promised love:
In pride whereof, he drew me forth this purse,
And swore, by this he multiplied his gold.
I tried and found it true: and secretly
Commanded music with her silver tongue,
To chime soft lullabies into his soul,
And whilst my fingers wantoned with his hair,
(T'entice the sleepy juice to charm his eyes)
In all points was there made a purse, like his,
Which counterfet is hung in place of this.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: More than a second kingdom hast thou won.
Leave him, that when he wakes he may suspect,
Some else has robbed him, come dear Agrippine,
If this strange purse his sacred virtues hold,
We'll circle England with a waist of gold. Exeunt.

div.stage: Music still: enter Saddow very gallant, reading a bill, with empty bags in his hand singing.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
These English occupiers are mad Trojans: let a man pay them never so much, they'll give him nothing but the bag. Since my master created me steward over his fifty
men, and his one and fifty horse, I have rid over much business, yet never was galled, I thank the destinies: music? O delicate warble: oh these courtiers are most sweet triumphant creatures. Signior, sir: monsieur: sweet signior; this is the language of theaccomplishment: oh delicious strings: these heavenly wire-drawers have stretched my master even out at length: yet at length he must wake: master?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Wake me not yet, my gentle Agrippine.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: One word sir, for the billets, and I vanish.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: There's heaven in these times: throw the musicians a bounteous largesse of thrée hundred angels. Andelocia starts up.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Why sir, I have but ten pound left.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Ha, Shadow? where's the Princess Agrippine?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I am not Apollo, I cannot reveal.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Was not the Princess here, when thou cam'st in?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Here was no Princess but my princely self.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: In faith?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: No in faith, sir.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Where are you hid? where stand you wantoning? Not here? gone i'faith? have you given me the slip? well, 'tis but an amorous trick and so I embrace it: my horse, Shadow, how fare my horse?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Upon the best oats my underiteward can buy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I mean, are they lusty, sprightly, gallant, wanton, fiery?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: They are as all horses are, caterpillars to the commonwealth, they are ever munching: but sir, for these billets, and these faggots and bavins?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: S'hart what billets, what faggots? dost make me a woodmonger?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: No sweet signior, but you have bid the King and his peers to dinner, and he has commanded that no woodmonger sell you a stick of wood, and that no collier shall cozen you of your measure, but must tie up the mouth of their sacks, lest their coals kindle your choler.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Is't possible? is't true, or hast thou learned of the English gallants to gull?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: He's a gull that would be taught by such gulls.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p:
Not a stick of wood? Some child of envy has buzzed this stratagem into the King's ear, of purpose to disgrace me: I have invited his majesty, and though it cost me a million, I'll feast him: shadow, thou shalt hire a hundred or two of carts, with them post to all the grocers in London, buy up all the cinnamon, cloves, nutmegs, liquorish and all other spices, that have any strong heart, and with them make fires to prepare our cookery:
Ere Fortunatus' son look red with shame,
He'll dress a King's feast in a spiced flame.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: This device, sir, will be somewhat a kin to lady pride, 'twill ask cost.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Fetch twenty porters, I'll laid all with gold.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: First, master, fill these bags.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Come then, hold up, how now? tricks, new crochets, madam fortune? Dry as an eel-skin? Shadow, take thou my gold out.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Why sir, here's none in.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Ha, let me see: oh here's a bastard cheek,
I see now 'tis not mine: 'tis counterfeit,
'Tis so: slave thou hast robbed thy master.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Not of a penny, I have been as true a steward.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Vengeance on thee and on thy stewardship.
Yet wherefore curse I thee? thy leaden soul
Had never power to mount up to the knowledge
Of the rich mystery closed in my purse.
O no, I'll curse myself, mine eyes I'll curse,
They have betrayed me, I will curse my tongue,
That hath betrayed me: I'll curse Agrippine,
She hath betrayed me: Sirens cease to sing,
Your charms have ta'en effect, for now I see,
All your enchantments were, to cozen me. Music ceaseth.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: What shall I do with this ten pound, sir?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Go buy with it a chain and hang thyself.
Now think I on my father's prophecy.
Tell none (Quoth he) the virtue, if you do,
Much shame, much grief, much danger follows you.
With tears I credit his divinity.
O fingers, were you upright justices,
You would tear out mine eyes: had not they gazed
On the frail colour of a painted cheek,
None had betrayed me: henceforth I'll defy
All beauty, and will call a lovely eye,
A sun whose scorching beams burn up our joys,
Or turn them black like Ethiopians.
O women, wherefore are you born men's woe,
Why are your faces framed angelical?
Your hearts of sponges, soft and smooth in show,
But touched, with poison they do overflow.
Had sacred wisdom been my father's fate,
He had died happy, I lived fortunate.
Shadow, be are this to beauteous Agrippine,
With it this message, tell her, I'll reprove
Her covetous sin the less, because for gold,
I see that most men's souls too cheap are sold.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Shall I buy these spices today or tomorrow ▪

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Tomorrow? Ay, tomorrow thou shalt buy them,
Tomorrow tell the Princess I will love her,
Tomorrow tell the King, I'll banquet him,
Tomorrow, Shadow, will I give thee gold,
Tomorrow pride goes bare and lust acold.
Tomorrow will the rich man feed the poor.
And vice tomorrow virtue will adore,
Tomorrow beggars shall be crowned Kings,
This no-time, morrows-time, no sweetness sings:
I pray thee hence: bear that to Agrippine.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I'll go hence, because you send me: but I'll go weeping hence, for grief that I must turn villain as many do, and leave you when you are up to the ears in adversity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: She hath robbed me, and now I'll play the thief,
I'll steal from hence to Cyprus, for black shame.
Here (Through my riots) brands my lofty name.
I'll sell this pride for help to bear me thither,
So pride and beggary shall walk together:
This world is but a school of villainy,
Therefore I'll rob my brother, (Not of gold,
Nor of his virtues, virtue none will steal:)
But (If I can,) I'll steal his wishing hat.
And with that, wand'ring round about the world,
I'll search all corners to find misery,
And where she dwells, I'll dwell, languish and die. Exit.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Gentles, if ere you have beheld the passions,
The combats of his soul who being a King,
By some usurping hand hath been deposed
From all his royalties: even such a soul,
Such eyes, such heart swollen big with sighs and tears,
The star-crossed son of Fortunatus wears.
The thoughts crowned him a monarch in the morn,
Yet now he's bandied by the seas in scorn,
From wave to wave: his golden treasure's spoil
Makes him in desperate language to entreat,
The winds to spend their fury on his life:
But they (Being mild in tyranny) or scorning
To triumph in a wretch's funeral,
Toss him to Cyprus. O what treachery
Cannot this serpent gold entice us to?
He robs his brother of the soldan's prize,
And having got his wish (The wishing hat)
He does not (As he vowed) seek misery,
But hopes by that to win his purse again,
And in that hope from Cyprus is he fled.
If your swift thoughts clap on their wonted wings,
In Genua may you take this fugitive,
Where having cozened many jewellers,
To England back he comes, step but to court,
And there (Disguised) you find him bargoning
For jewels with the beauteous Agrippine,
Who wearing at her side the virtuous purse,
he clasps her in his arms, and as a raven,
Gripping the tender-hearted nightingale,
So flies he with her, (Wishing) in the air,
To be transported to some wilderness:Enter Andelocia and Agripyne.
Imagine this the place: see here they come.
Since they themselves have tongues, mine shall be dumb.

div.stage: Exit.
Enter Andelocia with the wishing hat on: Agrippina in his hand.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: What devil art thou that affrightest me thus,
Haling a Princess from her father's court,
To spoil her in this savage wilderness?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Indeed the devil and the pickpurse should always fly together, (For they are sworn brothers:) but madam covetousness, I am neither a devil as you call me, nor a jeweller's as I call myself, no, nor a juggler, yet ere you and I part, we'll have some legerdemain together: do you know me?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I am betrayed: this is the cypriot.
Forgive me, 'twas not I that change thy purse,
But Athelstane my father, send me home,
And here's thy purse again: here are thy jewels,
And I in satisfaction of all wrongs.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Talk not you of satisfaction, this is some recompense that I have you, 'tis not the purse I regard: put if off, and I'll mince it as small as pie meat: the purse? hang the purse: were that gone, I can make another, and another, and another, I and another: 'tis not the purse I care for, but the purser: you, I you. Is't not a shame that a King's daughter, a fair lady, a lady not for lords, but for monarchs, should for gold sell her love, and when she has her own asking, and that there stands nothing between, than to cheat your sweet heart? O fie, fie, a she coney-catcher? You must be dealt soundly with.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Enjoin what pains thou wilt, and I'll endure them, so thou wilt send me to my father's court.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p:
Nay god's lid, you're not gone so: set your heart at rest, for I have set up my rest, that except you can run swifter than a hart, home you go not: what pains shall I lay upon
you? Let me see: I could serve you now but a slippery touch: I could get a young King or two, or three of you, and then send you home, and bid their grandsire King nurse them: I could pepper you, but I will not.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O, do not violate my chastity.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: No, why I tell you I am not given to the flesh, though I savour (In your nose) a little of the devil, I could run away else, and starve you here.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: If I must die, doom me some easier death.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Or transform you (Because you love picking) into a squirrel, and make you pick out a poor living here among the nut trees: but I will not neither.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: What will my gentle Andelocia do?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: O, now you come to your old bias of cogging.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I pray thee Andelocia, let me go:
Send me to England, and by heaven I swear,
Thou from all Kings on earth my love shalt bear.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Shall I in faith?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: In faith, in faith thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Here, god a mercy: now thou shalt not go.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Nay do you hear lady? cry not you're best: no nor curse me not: if you think but a crabbed thought of me, the spirit that carried you in mine arms through the air, will tell me all: therefore set your Sunday face upon't. Since you'll love me, I'll love you, I'll marry you, and lie with you, and beget little jugglers: marry home you get not: England you'll say is yours: but Agrippine, love me, and I will make the whole world thine.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I care not for the world, thou murder'st me,
Between my sorrow, and the scalding sun
I faint, and quickly will my life be done,
My mouth is like a furnace, and dry heat
Drinks up my blood. O God, my heart will burst,
I die, unless some moisture quench my thirst.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: S'hart now I am worse than ere I was before:
For half the world I would not have her die.
Here's neither spring nor ditch, nor rain, nor dew,
nor bread, nor drink: my lovely Agrippine,
Be comforted, see here are apple trees.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Climb up for god's sake, reach me some of them.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Look up, which of these apples likes thee best?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: This hath a withered face, 'tis some sweet fruit.
Not that, my sorrows are too sour already.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Come hither, here are apples like gold.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O, I for God's sake, gather some of these.
Ay me, would God I were at home again. Climes up.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Stand farther, lest I chance to fall on thee.
O here be rare apples, rare red-cheeked apples, that cry come
Kiss me ▪ apples, hold your peace, I'll teach you to cry. Eats one.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O England, shall I never behold thee more?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Agrippina, 'tis a most sugared delicious taste in ones mouth, but when 'tis down, 'tis as bitter as gall.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Yet gather some of them. O, that a Princess
Should pine for food: were I at home again,
I should disdain to stand thus and complain.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Here's one apple that grows highest, Agrippina, and I could reach that, I'll come down.

div.stage: He stands fishing with his girdle for it,

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Make haste, for the hot sun doth scald my cheeks.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: The sun kiss thee? hold, catch, put on my hat, I will have yonder highest apple, though I die for't.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I had not wont be sunburnt, wretched me.
O England, would I were again in thee. Exit. He leaps down.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: 'Swounds Agrippina, stay, oh I am undone,
Sweet Agrippina, if thou hearst my voice,
Take pity of me, and return again ▪
She flies like lightning: oh she hears me not,
I wish myself into a wilderness,
And now I shall turn wild: here I shall famish,
Here die, here cursing die, here raving die,
And thus will wound my breast, and rent mine hair.
What hills of flint are grown upon my brows?
O me, two forked horns, I am turned beast,
I have abused two blessings, wealth and knowledge,
wealth in my purse, and knowledge in my hat,
By which being born into the courts of Kings,
I might have seen the wondrous works of Jove,
Acquired experience, learning, wisdom, truth,
But I in wilderness tottered out my youth,
And therefore must turn wild: must be a beast,
An ugly beast: my body horns must bear,
Because my soul deformity doth wear.
Lives none within this wood? If none but I
Live here (Thanks heaven) for here none else shall die.

div.stage: He lies down and sleeps under the tree: enter fortune, vice, virtue, the priest: satires with music, playing as they come in before fortune. They play awhile.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: See where my new-turned devil has built his hell.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Virtue, who conquers now? the fool is ta'en.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: O sleepy sin. Music awhile, and then cease.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Sweet tunes wake him again.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Vice sets too heavy on his drowsy soul,
Music sweet concord cannot pierce his ear.
Sing and amongst your songs, mix bitter scorn.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Those that tear virtue, must by vice be torn.
Virtue stand aside: the fool is caught,

sp.speaker: 1. Verse.
sp.l: Laugh to see him, laugh aloud to wake him,
Follies nets are wide, and neatly wrought,
Mock his horns, and laugh to see vice take him.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,Andel. wakens and stands up.
Who's that fool? the fool, he wears a horn.
Virtue stand aside, mock him, mock him, mock him

sp.speaker: 2. Verse.
sp.l: Laugh aloud to see him, call him fool.
Error gave him suck, now sorrow's rock him,
Send the riotous beast to madness school.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,
Who's the fool? the fool, he wears a horn.
Virtue stand aside: your school he hates.

sp.speaker: 3. Verse.
sp.l: Laugh aloud to see him, mock, mock, mock him.
Vanity and hell keep open gates,
He's in, and a new nurse (Despair) must rock him.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,
Fool, fool, fool, fool, fool, wear still the horn.

div.stage: When they have done singing, vice and virtue hold apples out to him, vice laughing, virtue grieving.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O me, what hell is this? fiends, tempt me not.
Thou glorious devil hence. O now I see,
This fruit is thine, thou hast deformed me:
Idiot avoid, thy gifts I loathe to taste.
Away: since I am entered madness school,
As good to be a beast, as be a fool.
Away, why tempt you me? some powerful grace
Come and redeem me from this hideous place.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: To her hath Andelocia (All his life)
Sworn fealty, wouldst thou forsake her now?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Whose blessed tongue names Andelocia?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Hers, who (Attended on by destinies)
Shortened thy father's life, and lengthens thine. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O sacred Queen of chance, now shorten mine,
Else let thy deity take off this shame.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Woo her, was she that set it on thy head.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: She laughs to see me metamorphosed.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Woo me and I'll take off this ugly scorn. Rises.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Woo me, and I'll clap on another horn.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: I am beset with anguish, shame and death.
O bid the fates work fast, and stop my breath.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: No Andelecia, thou must live to see
Worse torments (For thy follies) light on thee.
This golden tree, which did thine eyes entice,
Was planted here by vice: lo, here stands vice:
How often hast thou sued to win her grace?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Till now, I never did behold her face.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Thou didst behold her at thy father's death,
When thou in scorn didst violate his will,
Thou didst behold her, when thy stretched-out arm
catched at the highest bough, the loftiest vice,
The fairest apple, but the foulest price.
Thou didst behold her, when thy liquorish eye
Fed on the beauty of fair Agrippine,
Because thou'dst gold, thou thoughtst all women thine,
When lookest thou off from her? for they whose souls
Still revel in the nights of vanity,
On the fair cheeks of vice still fix their eye.
Because her face doth shine, and all her bosom
Bears silver moons, thou wast enamoured of her.
But hadst thou upward looked, and seen these shames,
Or viewed her round about, and in this glass
Seen idiot's faces, heads of devils and hell,
And read this ha, ha, he, this merry story,
Thou wouldst have loathed her: where, by loving her,
Thou bearest this face, and wearest this ugly head,
And if she once can bring thee to this place,
Loud sounds these ha, ha, he, she'll laugh apace.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O, retransform me to a glorious shape,
And I will learn how I may love to hate her.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: I cannot retransform thee, woo this woman.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: This woman? wretched is my state, when I,
To find out wisdom, to a fool must fly.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Fool, clear thine eyes, this is bright Arete,
This is poor virtue, care not how the world
Doth crown her head, the world laughs her to scorn,
Yet sibi sapit, virtue knows her worth.
Run after her, she'll give thee these and these
Crowns and bay-garlands: (Honours victories:)
Serve her, and she will fetch thee pay from heaven,
Or give thee some bright office in the stars.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Immortal Arete, virtue divine,Kneels.
O smile on me, and I will still be thine.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Smile thou on me, and I will still be thine:
Though I am jealous of thy apostasy,
I'll entertain thee: here, come taste this tree,
Here's physic for thy sick deformity.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: 'Tis bitter: this fruit I shall never digest.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Try once again, the bitterness soon dies.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Mine's sweet, taste mine.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: But being down 'tis sour,
And mine being down has a delicious taste.
The path that leads to virtue's court is narrow,
Thorny and up a hill, a bitter journey
But being gone through, you find all heavenly sweets,
The entrance is all flinty, but at th'end,
To towers of pearl and crystal you ascend.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: O delicate, oh sweet ambrosian relish,
And see, my ugliness drops from my brows,
Thanks beauteous Arete: oh had I now
My hat and purse again, how I would shine,
And gild my soul with none but thoughts divine.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: That shall be tried, take fruit from both these trees,
By help of them, win both thy purse and hat,
I will instruct thee how, for on my wings
To England shalt thou ride; thy virtuous brother
Is (With that shadow who attends on thee,)
In London, there I'll set thee presently.
But if thou lose our favours once again,
To taste her sweets, those sweets must prove thy bane.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Vice, who shall now be crowned with victory?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: She that triumphs at last, and that must I.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Athelstane, Lincoln with Agripyne, Cyprus, Galloway, Cornwall, Chester, Longavile and Montrosse.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Lincoln, how settest thou her at liberty?

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: No other prison held her but your court,
There (In her chamber) hath she hid herself
These two days, only to shake off that fear,
Which her late violent rapture cast upon her.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Where hath the beauteous Agrippina been?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: In heaven or hell, in or without the world,
I know not which, for as I oft have seen
(When angry Thamesis hath curled her locks,)
A whirlwind come, and from her frizeld brows,
Snatch up a handful of those sweaty pearls,
That stood upon her forehead, which awhile,
Being by the boisterous wind hung in the air,
At length hath flung them down and raised a storm.
Even with such fury was I wherried up,
And by such force held prisoner in the clouds,
And thrown by such a tempest down again.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Some soul is damned in hell for this black deed.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I have the purse safe, and anon your grace
Shall hear this wondrous history at full.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Tell me, tormenter, shall fair Agrippine,
Without more difference be now christened mine?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: My choice must be my father's fair consent.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Then shall thy choice end in this Cyprus prince.
Before the sun shall six times more arise,
His royal marriage will we solemnise.
Proclaim this honoured match, come Agrippine,
I am glad thou'rt here, more glad the purse is mine.

div.stage: As they are all going in: enter Andelocia and Shaddowe, like Irish costermongers, Agrippina, Longavyle, and Montrosse stay listening to them, the rest exeunt.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Buy any apples, féene apples of Tamasco, féene Tamasio peepeins: peeps feene, buy Tamasco pippins.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Damasco apples? good my lord Montrosse,
Call yonder fellows.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.p: Sirrah costermonger.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Who calls: peeps of Tamasco, féene peeps: I sat 'tis de sweetest apple in de world, 'tis better den de pomewater, or apple John.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: By my trat madam, 'tis réet Tamasco pippins, look here else.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I dare not say, as de Irishman my countryman say, taste de goodness of de fruit: no faith 'tis fairy téere mistress, by saint Patrick's hand 'tis téere Tamasco apple.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The fairest fruit that ever I beheld,
Damasco apples, wherefore are they good?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: What is your price of half a score of these?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Half a score, half a score? dat is doos many mester.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ten, half a score, that's five and five.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Féeue and feeve? By my trat and as Créeze save me la, I cannot tell, what be de price of feeve and feeve, but 'tis tree crown for one pippin, dat is the préez if you take 'em.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I fat, 'tis no less for Tamasco.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Thrée crowns for one? what wondrous virtues have they?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: O, 'tis féene Tamasco apple, and shall make you a great teale wise, and make you no fool, and make feene memory.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: And make dis fash be more fair and amiable, and make dis eyes look always lovely, and make all de court and country burn in desire to kiss di none sweet countenance.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Apples to make a lady beautiful?
Madam that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: These Irishmen,
Some say, are great dissemblers, and I fear,
These two the badge of their own country wear.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: By my trat, and by saint Patrick's hand, and as Créez save me la, 'tis no dissembler: de Irish man now and den cut di countryman's throat, but yet in faith he love di countryman, 'tis no dissembler: dis féene Tamasco apple can make di sweet countenance, but I can take no less but thrée crowns for one, I wear out my naked legs and my foots, and my toes, and run hidder and didder to Tamasco for dem.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: As Créez save me la, he speaks true: peeps feene,

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I'll try what power lies in Damasco fruit.
Here are ten crowns for thrée, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.p: Lord Longavile, buy some.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I buy? not I:
Hang them, they are toys, come madam, let us go. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Saint Patrick and saint Peter, and all de holy angels look upon dat fash and make it fair.

div.stage: Enter Montrosse softly.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, she's sped, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Peace, Shadow, buy any pippins, buy.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Peeps féene, féene Tamasco apples.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.p: Came not lord Longavile to buy some fruit?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: No fat, master, here came no lords nor ladies, but di none sweet self.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.p: 'Tis well, say nothing, here's six crowns for two: you say the virtues are to make one strong.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes fat and make sweet countenance and strong too.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent, here: farewell, if these prove,
I'll conquer men by strength, women by love. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Longavyle.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why this is rare.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Peace, master, here comes another fool.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Peeps féene, buy any peeps of Tamasco?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: Did not the lord Montrosse return to you?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: No fat, sweet master, no lord did turn to us: peeps féene.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: I am glad of it: here are nine crowns for thee: what are the virtues besides making fair?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: O, 'twill make thee wondrous wise.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: And dow shall be no more a fool, but sweet face and wise.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: 'Tis rare, farewell ▪ I never yet durst woo.
None loves me: now I'll try what these can do. Exit.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. So, this is admirable, Shadow, here end my torments in saint Patrick's purgatory, but thine shall continue longer.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Did I not clap on a good false Irish face?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: It became thee rarely.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Yet that's lamentable, that a false face should become any man.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Thou art a gull, 'tis all the fashion now, which fashion because we'll keep, step thou abroad, let not the world want fools: whilst thou art commencing thy knavery there, I'll proceed doctor Dodipoll here: that done, thou Shadow
and I will fat ourselves to behold the transformation of these fools: go fly.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I fear nothing, but that whilst we strive to make others fools, we shall wear the coxcombs ourselves, pips fine etc. Exit Shadow.

div.stage: Enter Ampedo.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: S'hart, here's my brother whom I have abused:
His presence makes me blush, it strikes me dead,
To think how I am metamorphosed.
Féene paepins of Tamasco etc.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: For shame cast off this mask.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Wilt thou buy any pips?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Mock me no longer
With idle apparitions: many a land
Have I with weary feet and a sick soul
Measured, to find thee; and when thou art found,
My greatest grief is, that thou art not lost:
Yet lost thou art, thy fame, thy wealth are lost,
Thy wits are lost, and thou hast in their stead,
With shame and cares, and misery crowned thy head.
That Shadow that pursues thee, filled mine ears
With sad relation of thy wretchedness,
Where is the purse, and where my wishing hat?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Where? and where? are you created constable, you stand so much upon intergatories? the purse is gone, let that fret you, and the hat is gone, let that mad you: I run thus through all trades to overtake them, if you'll be quiet, follow me, and help, if not, fly from me, and hang yourself: wilt thou buy any pippins? Exit.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O, how I grieve, to see him thus transformed?
Yet from the circles of my jealous eyes,
He shall not start, till he have repossessed
Those virtuous jewels, which found once again,
More cause they never shall give me to complain.
Their worth shall be consumed in murdering flames,
And end my grief, his riot, and our shames. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Athelstane, Agripyne, Montrosse and Longavyle with horns, Lincoln and Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: In spite of sorcery try once again,
Try once more in contempt of all damned spells.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Your majesty fights with no mortal power.
Shame and not conquest, hangs upon his strife.
O, touch me not, you add but pain to pain,
The more you cut, the more they grow again.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: Is there no art to conjure down this scorn?
Ay, never knew physic yet against the horn.

div.stage: Enter Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: See, prince of Cyprus, thy fair Agrippine
Hath turn her beauty to deformity.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Then I defy thee, love, vain hopes, adieu,
You have mocked me long; in scorn I'll now mock you.
I came to see how the lord Longavile
Was turned into a monster, and I find
And object, which both strikes me dumb and blind.
Tomorrow should have been our marriage morn,
But now my bride is shame, thy bridegroom scorn.
O tell me yet, is there no art, no charms,
No desperate physic for this desperate wound?

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: All means are tried, but no means can be found.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Then England, farewell: hapless maid, thy stars,
Through spiteful influence set our hearts at wars.
I am enforced to leave thee, and resign
My love to grief.

div.stage: Enter Orleans and Galloway.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: All grief to Agrippine.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Adieu I would say more, had I a tongue
Able to help his master: mighty King,
I humbly take my leave, to Cyprus I,
My father's son, must all such shame defy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: So doth not Orleans, I defy all those,
That love not Agrippine, and him defy,
That dares but 〈◊〉 her half so well as I.
Oh pardon me, I have in sorrow's jail,
been long tormented, long this mangled bosom
Hath bled, and never durst expose her wounds,
Till now, till now, when at thy beauteous feet,
I offer love and life, oh cast an eye
Of mercy on me, this deformed face
Cannot affright my soul from loving thee.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Talk not of love, good Orleans, but of hate.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: What sentence will my love pronounce on me?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Will Orleans then be mad ▪ oh gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: O gentle, gentle friend I am not mad:
He's mad, whose eyes on painted cheeks do dote,
Oh Galloway; such read beauty's book by rote.
He's mad, that pines for want of a gay flower,
Which saves when grief doth blast, or sickness lower,
Which heat doth wither, and white ages frost
Nips dead: such fairness, when 'tis found, 'tis lost,
I am not mad, for loving Agrippine,
My love looks on her eyes, with eyes divine,
I dote on the rich brightness of her mind,
That sacred beauty strikes all other blind,
Oh make me happy then, since my desires
Are set a burning by love's purest fires.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: So thou wilt bear her far from England sight,
Enjoy thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Lock me in some cave,
Where staring wonders eye shall not be guilty
To my abhorred looks, and I will die
To thee, as full of love as misery.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: I am amazed and mad, some speckled soul
Lies pawned for this in hell, without redemption,
Some fiend deludes us all.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: O unjust fates,
Why do you hide from us this mystery?

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: My lord Montrosse, how long have your brows worn
This fashion? these two feather-springs of horn?

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: An Irish kern sold me Damasco apples,
Some two hours since, and (Like credulous fool)
he swearing to me that they had this power,
To make me strong in body, rich in mind,
I did believe his words, tasted his fruit,
And since have been attired in this disguise.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I fear that villain hath beguiled me too.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Nay before God he has not cozened you,
You have it soundly.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Me he made believe,
One apple of Damasco would inspire
By thoughts with wisdom, and upon my cheeks
Would cast such beauty, that each lady's eye,
Which looked on me, should love me presently.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Desire to look more fair, makes me more soul,
Those apples did entice my wand'ring eye,
To be enamoured of deformity.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: This proves that true, which oft I have heard in schools,
Those that would seem most wise do turn most fools.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: Here's your best hope, nene needs to hide his face,
For horned foreheads swarm in every place.

div.stage: Enter Chester bringing Andelocia like a French doctor.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Now Chester, what physicians hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Many, my liege, but none that have true skill
To tame such wild diseases: yet here's one,
A doctor and a Frenchman, whom report
Of Agrippina's grief hath drawn to court.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Cure her, and England's treasury shall stand,
As free for thee to use, as rain from heaven.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Cure me and to thy coffers I will send,
More gold from Scotland than thy life can spend.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Cure Longavile, and all his wealth is thine.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
He monsieur Long-villain gra tank you: gra tanck your mashestie a great teale artely by my trat: where be dis madam Princeza dat be so much tormenta? O ieshu : one, 2: an tree, 4 and 5, seez horn ha, ha, ha, pardona moy prea wid all mine art, for by my trat, me can no point shose but laugh,
ha, ha, ha ▪ to mark how like tree bul-beggera, day stand. O, by my trat and fat, di divela be whoreson, scurvy, paltry, ill savour knave to mock de madam, and gentill-home so: ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.p: This doctor comes to mock your majesty.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p: No by my trat la, but me lova musha musha merriment: come madam, prea-artely stand still, and letta me seel your dis horn, oh 'tis pretty horn, dis be facile, easy for pull de vey but madame dis o he grand, grand horn, difficile, and very deep, 'tis perilous, a grand laroone. But madam, pray be patient, we shall take it off vell.

sp.speaker: A●●e.
sp.p: Thrice have we pared them off, but with fresh pain, in compass of a thought they rise again.

sp.speaker: A●●●l.
sp.p: Its true, 'tis no easy mattra, to pull horn off, 'tis easy for pull on, but hard for pull off, some horn be so good fellow, he will still inhabit in de man's pate, but 'tis all one for that, I shall snap away all dis: madam trust dis down into your little belly.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Father, I am in fear to taste his physic.
First let him work experiments on those.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: I'll sauce you for your infidelity. Aside.
In no place can I spy my wishing hat.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thou learned Frenchman, try thy skill on me,
More ugly than I am, I cannot be.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.p: Cure me, and Montrosse wealth shall all be thine.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for dat: shall do presently; madam, prea mark me: monsieur, shamp dis in your two shaps, so, now monsieur Long-villain, dis so: now dis, fear noting, 'tis eshelent medicine: so, now cram dis into your guts, and belly: so, now snap away dis whoreson four divela; ha, ha, is no point good? Puts Galloways horns off.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: This is most strange.
Wast painful Longavile?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: Ease took them off, and there remains no pain.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O try thy sacred physic on me.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
No by my trat, 'tis no possibla, 'tis no possibla, all de mattra, all de ting, all de substance, all de medicine, be among
his and his belly ▪ 'tis no possibla, till me prepare more.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.p: Prepare it then, and thou shalt have more gold from England's coffers, than thy life can waste.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: I much buy many costily tings dat grow in Arabia, in Asia, and America, by my trat 'tis no possibla, till another time, no point.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: There's nothing in the world, but may for gold
Be bought in England, hold your lap I'll rain
A shower of angels.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie, fie, you no credit le dockature? Ha, but vel, 'tis all one for that: 'tis no mattera for gold: vel, vel, vel, vel, vel, me have some more, prea say noting, shall be presently prepara for your horns.

lg.l: She has my purse, and yonder lies my hat,
Work brains, and once more make me fortunate.

sp.p: Vel, vel, vel, vel, be patient madam, presently, presently, be patient, me have two, tree, four and five medicines for de horn: presently madam, stand you der, prea wid all mine art, stand you all der: and say noting, so: nor look noting dis vey: so, presently, presently madam, snip dis horn off wid de rushes and another ting by and by, by and by, by and by, prea look none dis vey, and say noting. Gets his hat up.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Let no man speak, or look, upon his life.
Doctor, none here shall rob thee of thy skill.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: So, taka dis hand: wink now prea artely wid your two nyes: why so.
Would I were with my brother Ampedo. Exit with her.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Help, father, help, I am hurried hence perforce.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Draw weapons, where's the Princess, follow him,
Stay the French doctor, stay the doctor there.
Cornwall and some other run out, and enter presently.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Stay him, sh'art who dare stay him? 'tis the devil
In likeness of a Frenchman, of a doctor.
Look how a rascal kite having swept up
A chicken in his claws, so flies this hellhound
In th'air with Agrippine in his arms.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: Count every man upon his swiftest horse.
Fly several ways, he cannot bear her far.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: These paths we'll beat. Exeunt Gall. And Orleans.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: And this way shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: This way, my liege, I'll ride.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: And this way I:
No matter which way, to seek misery. Exit athelst.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.p: I can ride no way, to outrun my shame.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Yes, Longavile, let's gallop after too,
Doubtless this doctor was that Irish devil,
That cozened us, the medicine which he gave us,
Tasted like his Damasco villainy.
To horse, to horse, if we can catch this fiend,
Our forked shame shall in his heart blood end.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: O how this mads me, that all tongues in scorn,
Which way soe'er I ride, cry, beware the horn. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Andelocia, with Agripyne, Ampedo and Shadow.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O gentle Andelocia pity me,
Take off this infamy, or take my life.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Your life? you think then that I am a true doctor indeed, that tie up my lining in the knots of winding sheets: your life? no, keep your life, but deliver your purse: you know the thief's salutation, stand and deliver. So, this is mine, and these yours: I'll teach you to live by the sweat of other men's brows.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: And to strive to be fairer than God made her.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Right, Shadow: therefore vanish, you have made me turn juggler, and cry hey-pass, but your horns shall not repass.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O gentle Andelocia.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Andelocia is a nettle: if you touch him gently, he'll sting you.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Or a rose, if you pull his sweet stalk, he'll prick you.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Therefore not a word, go, trudge to your father: sigh not for your purse, money may be got by you, as well as by the little Welsh woman in Cyprus, that had but one horn in her head, you have two; and perhaps you shall cast both: as
you use me, mark those words well, as you use me, nay, you're best fly, I'll not endure one word more. Yet stay too, because you entreat me so gently, and that I'll make some amends to your father, although I care not for any King in Christendom, yet hold you, take this apple, eat it as you go to court, and your horns shall play the cowards and fall from you.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O gentle Andelocia.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Nay away, not a word.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, etc. ware horns. Exit Agrip. weeping.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Why dost thou laugh, Shadow?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: To see what a horn plague follows covetousness and pride.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Brother, what mysteries lie in all this?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Tricks, Ampedo, tricks, devises, and mad hieroglyphics, mirth, mirth, and melody. O, there's more music in this, than all the gamut ears, and sol fa res, in the world; here's the purse, and here's the hat: because you shall be sure I'll not start, wear you this, you know his virtue; if danger beset you, fly and away: a sort of broken-shinned limping legged jades run hobbling to seek us: Shadow, we'll for all this have one fit of mirth more, to make us laugh and be fat.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: And when we are fat, master, we'll do as all gluttons do, laugh and lie down.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Hie thee to my chamber, make ready my richest attire, I'll to court presently.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: I'll go to court in this attire, for apparel is but the shadow of a man, but shadow is the substance of his apparel. Exit Shadow.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Away, away, and meet me presently.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I had more need to cry, away to thee.
Away, away with this wild lunacy,
Away with riots.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Away with your purity, brother, you're an ass, why doth this purse spit out gold but to be spent? why lives a man in this world, to dwell in the suburbs of it, as you do? Away foreign simplicity, away: are not eyes made to see fair
ladies: hearts to love them? tongues to court them, and hands to feel them? Out you stock, you stone, you logs end: are not legs made to dance, and shall mine limp up and down the world after your cloth-stockin-héeles? you have the hat, keep it, anon I'll visit your virtuous countenance again, adieu, pleasure is my sweet mistress, I wear her love in my hat, and her soul in my heart: I have sworn to be merry, and in spite of fortune and the black-browed destinies, I'll never be sad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: Go, fool, in spite of mirth, thou shalt be sad.
I'll bury half thy pleasures in a grave
Of hungry flames, this fire I did ordain
To burn both purse and hat: as this doth perish,
So shall the other: count what good and bad
They both have wrought, the good is to the ill,
As a small pibble to a mighty hill.
Thy glory and thy mischiefs here shall burn,
Good gifts abused to man's confusion turn.

div.stage: Enter Longavile, and Montrosse with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: This is his brother; soldiers, bind his arms.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Bind arms and legs, and hale the fiend a way.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Uncivil: wherefore must I taste your spite?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Art thou not one of Fortunatus sons?

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: I am, but he did never do you wrong.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The devil thy brother has, villain, look here.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Where is the beauteous purse and wishing hat?

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: My brother Andelocia has the purse,
This way he'll come anon to pass to court,
Alas, that sin should make men's hearts so bold,
To kill their souls for the base thirst of gold.
The wishing hat is burned.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Burned? Soldiers bind him.
Tortures shall wring both hat and purse from you,
Villain, I'll be revenged for that base scorn,
Thy hellhound brother clapped upon my head.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: And so will Longavile.
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Drag him to yonder tower, there shackle him,
And in a pair of stocks, lock up his heels,
And bid your wishing cap deliver you.
Give us the purse and hat, we'll set thee free,
Else rot to death and starve.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O tyranny, you need not scorn the badge which you did bear:
Beasts would you be, though horns you did not wear.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Drag hence the cur: come noble Longavile,
One's sure, and were the other fiend as fast,
Their pride should cost their lives: their purse and hat
Shall be both ours, we'll share them equally.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: That will be some amends for arming me.

div.stage: Enter Andelocia and Shadow after him.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Peace, Longavile, yonder the gallant comes.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: You're well encountered.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Thanks, lord Longavile.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The King expects your presence at the court.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: And thither am I going.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Pips fine, fine apples of Tamasco, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Wert thou that Irishman that cozened us?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Pips fine, ha, ha, ha, no not I: not Shadow.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Were not your apples delicate and rare?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The worst that ere you sold; sirs, bind him fast.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: What, will you murder me? help, help, some help.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Help, help, help. Exit Shadow.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Follow that dog, and stop his balling throat.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Villains, what means this barbarous treachery?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: We mean to be revenged for our disgrace.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: And stop the golden current of thy waist.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Murder, they murder me, oh call for help.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thy voice is spent in vain, come, come, this purse,
This wellspring of your prodigality.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Are you appointed by the King to this?

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: No, no, rise, spurn him up: know you who's this?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: My brother Ampedo? Alas, what fate
Hath made thy virtues so infortunate?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Thy riot and the wrong of these two lords,
Who (Causeless) thus do starve me in this prison.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Strive not you're best, villains, lift in his legs.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Traitors to honour, what do you intend?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: That riot shall in wretchedness have end.
Question thy brother with what cost he's fed,
And so assure thou shalt be banqueted. Exeunt they two.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: In want, in misery, in woe and care,
Poor Ampedo his fill hath surfeited:
My want is famine, bolts my misery,
My care and woe should be thy portion.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Give me that portion, for I have a heart
Shall spend it freely, and make bankrupt
The proudest woe that ever wet man's eye.
Care with a mischief? wherefore should I care?
Have I rid side by side by mighty Kings,
Yet be thus bridled now? I'll tear these fetters.
Murder, cry murder, Ampedo, aloud.
To bear this scorn our fortunes are too proud.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O folly, thou hast power to make flesh glad,
When the rich soul in wretchedness is clad.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Peace, fool, am not I fortune's minion?
These bands are but one wrinkle of her frown,
This is her evening mask, her next morn's eye
Shall overshine the sun in majesty.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But this sad night will make an end of me.
Brother, farewell, grief, famine, sorrow, want,
Have made an end of wretched Ampedo.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Where is the wishing hat?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Consumed in fire.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Accursed be those hands that did destroy it,
That would redeem us, did we now enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Wanton farewell, I faint, death's frozen hand
Congeals life's little river in my breast.
No man before his end is truly blessed. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O miserable, miserable soul.
Thus a foul life makes death to look more foul.

div.stage: Enter Longavyle and Montrosse with a halter.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thus shall this golden purse divided be,
One day for you, another day for me.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Of days anon, say, what determine you,
Shall they have liberty, or shall they die?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Die sure: and see, I think the elder's dead.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Ay, murderers, he is dead. O sacred wisdom,
Had Fortunatus been enamoured
Of thy celestial beauty, his two sons
Had shined like two bright suns.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Pull hard, Montrosse.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Come you to strangle me? are you the hangman?
Hellhounds you're damned for this impiety.
Fortune, forgive me, I deserve thy hate,
Myself have made myself a reprobate:
Virtue, forgive me, for I have transgressed
Against thy laws, my vows are quite forgotten,
And therefore shame is fallen to my sin's lot.
Riches and knowledge are two gifts divine.
They that abuse them both as I have done,
To shame, to beggary, to hell must run.
O conscience hold thy sting, cease to afflict me.
Be quick, tormentors, I desire to die.
No death is equal to my misery.
Cyprus, vain world, and vanity farewell.
Who builds his heaven on earth, is sure of hell.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: He's dead: in some deep vault let's throw their bodies.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: First let us see the purse, lord Longavile.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Here 'tis, by this we'll fill this tower with gold.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Frenchman, this purse is counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thou liest.
Scot, thou hast cozened me, give me the right,
else shall thy bosom be my weapon's grave.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Villain, thou shalt not rob me of my due.

div.stage: They fight: enter Athelstane, Agrippina, Orleans, Galloway, Cornwall, Chester, Lincoln, and Shadow with weapons at one door: fortune, vice, and their attendants at another door.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Lay hands upon the murderers, strike them down.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Surrender up this purse, for this is mine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'll these two devils, of some powers divine?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: O, see, see, oh my two masters, poor shadows substances; what shall I do? whose body shall Shadow now follow?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Peace, idiot, thou shalt find rich heaps of fools,
That will be proud to entertain a shadow.
I charm thy babbling lips from troubling me.
You need not hold them, see, I smite them down
Lower than hell: base souls, sink to your heaven.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: I do arrest you both my prisoners.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Stand not amazed, you gods of earth, at this,
She that arresteth these two fools is vice,
They have broke virtues laws, vice is her sergeant,
Her jailer and her executioner.
Look on those Cypriots, Fortunatus sons,
They and their father were my minions,
My name is fortune.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O dread deity.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Kneel not to me: if fortune list to frown,
You need not fall down, for she'll spurn you down ▪
Arise, but fools, on you I'll triumph thus.
What have gained by being covetous?
This prodigal purse did fortune's bounteous hand
Bestow on them, their riots made them poor,
And set those marks of miserable death,
On all their pride, the famine of base gold
Hath made your souls to murders hands be sold,
only to be called rich but idiots see
The virtues to be fled, fortune hath caused it so,
Those that will all devour, must all forgo.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Most sacred goddess.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Peace, you flatterer.
Thy tongue but heaps more vengeance on thy head.
Fortune is angry with thee, in thee burns
A greedy covetous fire; in Agrippine
Pride like a monarch revels, and those sins
Have led you blindfold to your former shames,
But virtue pardoned you, and so doth fortune.

sp.speaker: Athelst. And Agrip.
sp.l: All thanks to both your sacred deities,

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: As for these metal-eaters, these base thieves,
Who rather than they would be counted poor,
Will dig through hell for gold, you were forgiven
By virtue's general pardon; her broad seal
Gave you your lives, when she took off your horns.
Yet having scarce one foot out of the jail,
You tempt damnation by more desperate means,
You both are mortal, and your pains shall ring
Through both your ears, to terrify your souls ▪
As please the judgement of this mortal King.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Fair empress of the world, since you resign
Your power to me, this sentence shall be mine,
Thou shalt be tortured on a wheel to death,
Thou with wild horses shalt be quartered.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Ha, ha, weak judge, weak judgement, I reverse
That sentence, for they are my prisoners,
Embalm the bodies of those Cypriots,
And honour them with princely burial,
For those do as you please, but for these two,
I kiss you both, I love you, you're my minions,
Untie their hands, vice doth reprieve you both,
I set you free.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thanks, gracious deity.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Be gone, but you in liberty shall find
more bondage than in chains, fools, get you hence,
Both wander with tormented conscience.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: O horrid judgement, that's the hell in deed.

sp.speaker: Monk
sp.l: Come, come, our death never ends if conscience bleed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: O miserable, miserable men. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Fortune triumphs at this, yet to appear,
All like myself, that which from those I took,
King Athelstane I will bestow on thee,
And in it the old virtue I infuse:
But, King, take heed how thou my gifts dost use.
England shall never be poor, it England strive,
Rather by virtue, then by wealth to thrive.

div.stage: Enter virtue, crowned: nymphs and King's attend on her, crowned with olive branches and laurels, music sounding.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Virtue? alas good soul, she hides her head.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: What envious tongue said, virtue hides her head?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: She that will drive thee into banishment.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: She that hath conquers thee; how dar'st thou come,
Thus tricked in gawdy feathers, and thus guarded,
Which crowned Kings and muses, when thy foe
Hath trod thus on thee, and now triumphs so?
Where's virtuous Ampedo? See, he's her slave,
For following thee this recompense they have.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Is Ampedo her stane? Why that's my glory.
The idiot's cap I once wore on my head,
Did figure him, those that (Like him) do muffle
Virtue in clouds, and care not how she shine,
I'll make their glory like to his decline:
He made no use of me, but like a miser,
Locked up his wealth in rusty bars of sloth:
His face was beautiful, but wore a mask,
And in the world's eyes seemed a blackamoor.
So perish they that so keep virtue poor.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Thou art a fool to strive, I am more strong,
And greater than thyself, than virtue fly,
And hide thy face, yield me the victory.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Is vice higher than virtue: that's my glory,
The higher that thou art, thou art more horrid,
The world will love me for my comeliness.

sp.speaker: Fortu.
sp.l: Thine own self loves thyself: why on the heads
Of Agrippine, Montresse and Longavile,
(English, Scot, French) did vice clap ugly horns,
But to approve that English, French and Scot,
And all the world else, kneel and honour vice,
But in no country, virtue is of price?

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Yes, in all country's virtue is of price.
In every kingdom some diviner breast
Is more enamoured of me then the rest.
Have English, Scot, and French bowed knees to thee?
Why that's my glory too, for by their shame,
Men will abhor thee and adore my name.
Fortune, thou art too weak, vice thou'rt a fool,
To fight with me, I suffered you awhile,
T'eclipse my brightness, but I now will shine,
And make you swear your beauty's base to mine.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Thou art too insolent, see here's a court
Of mortal judges, let's by them be tried,
Which of us three shall most be deified.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: So am not I.
My judge shall be your sacred deity.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: O miserable me, I am undone. Exit vice and her train.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O stop the horrid monster.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Let her run.
Fortune, who conquers now?

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Virtue, I see,
Thou wilt triumph both over her and me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Empress of heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Why do you mock me?
Kneel not to me, to her transfer your eyes,
There sits the Queen of chance, I bend my knees,
Lower than yours: dread goddess, 'tis most meet,
That fortune fall down at thy conquering feet.
Thou sacred empress that commandest the fates,
Forgive what I have to thy handmaid done,
And at thy chariot wheels fortune shall run,
And be thy captive and to thee resign
All powers which heavens large patent have made mine.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Fortune thou'rt vanquished: sacred deity,
Oh now pronounce who wins the victory,
And yet that sentence needs not, since alone,
Your virtuous presence vice hath overthrown,
Yet to confirm the conquest on your side,
Look but on Fortunatus and his sons
Of all the wealth those gallants did possess,
Only poor Shadow is left comfortless,
Their glory's faded and their golden pride.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Only poor shadow tells how poor they died.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: All that they had, or mortal men can have,
Sends only but a Shadow from the grave.
Virtue alone lives still, and lives in you,
I am a counterfeit. you are the true,
I am a Shadow, at your feet I fall,
Begging for these, and these, myself and all.
All these that thus do kneel before your eyes,
Are shadows like myself, dread nymph it lies
In you to make us substances. O do it,
Virtue I am sure you love, she woos you to it.
I read a verdict in your sunlike eyes,
And this it is: virtue the victory.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All loudly cry, virtue the victory.

sp.speaker: Virtue
sp.l: Virtue the victory: for joy of this,
Those self same hymns which you to fortune sung
Let them be now in virtue's honour rung ▪

div.head: The song.
div.l: Dimples on her cheeks do dwell,
Her love is heaven, her hate is hell.
Since heaven and hell obey her power,
Tremble when her eyes do lower.
Since heaven and hell her power obey,
And bend, and bend, and merrily,

div.stage: As they all offer to go in, enter the two old men.

sp.l: Nay stay, poor pilgrims, when I entered first
The circle of this bright celestial sphere,
I wept for joy, now I could weep for fear.
I fear we all like mortal men shall prove
Weak (Not in love) but in expressing love.
Let every one beg once more on his knee,
One pardon for himself, and one for me,
For I enticed you hither: oh dear goddess,
Breathe life in our nombd spirits with one smile,
And from this cold earth, we with lively souls
Shall rise like men (Newborn) and make heaven sound
With hymns sung to thy name, and prayers that we
May once a year so oft enjoy this sight,
Till these young boys change their curled locks to white,
And when gray-winged age sits on their heads,
That so their children may supply their steads,
And that heavens great arithmetician,
(Who in the scales of number weighs the world)
May still to forty two, and one year more,
And still add one to one, that went before,
And multiply four tens by many a ten:
To this I cry amen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen, amen.
Good night (Dear mistress) those that wish thee harm,
Thus let them stoop under destruction's arm.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen, amen, amen. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
